title-group.article-title: The Microbiota and Its Metabolites in Colonic Mucosal Health and Cancer Risk

article-meta.aff: 1Division of General Internal Medicine, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
2Division of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

author-notes.corresp: Stephen J. O’Keefe, MD, MSc, Professor of Medicine, Division of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, 200 Lothrop Street, PUH, Mezzanine Level–C Wing, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, USA; e-mail: sjokeefe@pitt.edu.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: Recent advances in our ability to identify and characterize the human microbiota have transformed our appreciation of the function of the colon from an organ principally involved in the reabsorption of secretory fluids to a metabolic organ on a par with the liver. High-throughput technology has been applied to the identification of specific differences in microbial DNA, allowing the identification of trillions of microbes belonging to more than 1000 different species, with a metabolic mass of approximately 1.5 kg. The close proximity of these microbes with the mucosa and gut lymphoid tissue helps explain why a balanced microbiota is likely to preserve mucosal health, whereas an unbalanced composition, as seen in dysbiosis, may increase the prevalence of diseases not only of the mucosa but also within the body due to the strong interactions with the gut immune system, the largest immune organ of the body. Such abnormalities have been pinpointed as etiological factors in a wide range of diseases, including autoimmune disorders, allergy, irritable bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, and colon cancer. Recognition of the strong potential for food to manipulate microbiota composition has opened up new therapeutic strategies against these diseases based on dietary intervention.

body.p: A very diverse group of microorganisms comprising bacteria, archaea, viruses, and unicellular eukaryotes resides within our gastrointestinal tract. The bacterial concentration varies, with their number increasing from 101 colony-forming units (cfu)/mL in the stomach, 103 cfu/mL in the duodenum, 104 cfu/mL in the jejunum, 107 cfu/mL in the ileum, to the maximum of 1012 cfu/mL in the colon, contributing to 60% of the fecal mass (Figure 1).1 The bacteria primarily belong to 2 major phyla, gram-positive Firmicutes and gram-negative Bacteroidetes, with other phyla such as Proteobacteria, Actinobacteria, Fusobacteria, Verrucomicrobia, and Cyanobacteria in minor proportions.2 They collectively form a 100-trillion super colony with more than 800 species and 7000 strains identified. They form a vibrant mass of foreign DNA, outnumbering the host in cell number by 10:1 and in DNA content by 150:1, weighing approximately 1–2 kg.3 They are initially acquired when maternal microbiota is passed on during the birth, breastfeeding, maternal skin, and environmental contact.4 After significant changes during the first year, the gross composition and distribution of microbiota remain quite stable thereafter over the years but are influenced by several factors such as diet, environment, geography, medication, radiation, surgery, stress, and disease.5,6

caption.p: Spatial and temporal aspects of intestinal microbiota composition. (A) Variations in microbial numbers and composition across the length of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. (B) Longitudinal variations in microbial composition in the intestine. (C) Temporal aspects of microbiota establishment and maintenance and factors influencing microbial composition. From Sekirov I et al.7 Copyright © 2010. Reprinted with permission from The American Physiological Society.

body.p: Their sheer numbers, diversity, and strict anaerobic nature make the characterization and identification of up to 80% of microbiota impossible by culturing.2 In the present genomic era, culture-independent identification of these microbes by techniques such as high-throughput gene sequencing and polymerized chain reaction (PCR) of conserved regions of microbial 16S rRNA has expanded our understanding of their diversity and composition.7 Analysis of the genomic content of the gut microbiota by metagenomics, metabolic profiling, and studying the influence of diet, toxins, disease, and microbiota by metabonomics have cast light on the contributions of the microbial world within us.8,9 Gnotobiology, the science of germ-free (GF) mice colonized with select microbial species to study their metabolic activities, has further helped us understand the host-microbe interaction in a simplified ecosystem.

Our lack of thorough understanding of the “core microbiota” to define “normal microbiota” hampers our ability to differentiate the “good” from the “bad” bacteria.10 The association alone of a particular microbiome with a disease does not necessarily imply the causality, so we have to be wary in interpreting these observations in speculating their role as causative agents of the disease. Innovative methods to influence the microbial composition and alter their metabolic behavior to benefit our health are areas of immense recent research interest.

sec.title: Microbiota and the Host: Symbiosis and Dysbiosis
sec.p: Although most ingested nutrients are digested along the gastrointestinal tract, a small percentage, mainly dietary fiber, resistant starch, and some protein, remains undigested. This represents the food for colonic microbiota that process these undigested material by fermentation to derive their own energy as well as produce metabolites that are key to the host energy homeostasis. The commensal bacteria prevent infections by enteric pathogenic organisms by competing for nutrition and producing bactericidal factors forming a “colonization resistance.”11 They assist host immune system regulation, process drug metabolites affecting their pharmacokinetics and adverse effect profile, and importantly synthesize vitamins such as biotin, folic acid, and vitamin K essential for the host, thereby representing an excellent example of symbiosis.12 The complexity of the physiological activities in the colon mediated by the microbiota makes it a metabolic organ in its own right.13 A variety of factors can disturb the composition, distribution, and metabolic activity of this ecosystem, resulting in a state of dysbiosis. These include antibiotics, psychological and physical stressors (a week of physical restraint at night resulted in a disturbed diversity of gut microbiota in a murine model and made them susceptible to infection when challenged by a murine enteric pathogen, Citrobacter rodentium), radiation, dysmotility (can cause bacterial overgrowth), surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass operation resulted in higher concentrations of Proteobacteria [52-fold] and lower concentrations of Firmicutes [4.5-fold] and Bacteroidetes [2-fold] in comparison with sham-operated rats), and dietary changes (Western diet rich in red meat and fat promotes carcinogenic hydrogen sulfide–producing bacteria).14-18

The microbiota ferments undigested carbohydrate residues preferentially in the proximal colon, yielding short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and gases hydrogen and methane. The undigested protein residues are fermented more distally, yielding branched SCFAs, hydrogen sulfide, ammonia, and several phenolic and indolic compounds.19,20 The major SCFAs produced are acetate, propionate, and butyrate in the ratio of 60:25:15.21 Other bacterial end products in minor proportions include lactate, ethanol, and other SCFAs (succinate, formate, valerate, caproate, isobutyrate, 2-methyl-butyrate, and isovalerate).22 The emerging field of metabolomics is revealing a vast array of microbial metabolites whose functions remain to be discovered.

SCFAs are significant sources of energy, contributing up to 10% of the daily calorie requirement in health, and may provide up to 1000 kcal/d in patients with short bowel syndrome where caloric salvage may permit survival.23 SCFAs lower the pH of the intracolonic milieu, which prevents the growth of pH-sensitive pathogenic bacteria, inhibits the degradation of primary bile acids to the carcinogenic secondary bile acids, and decreases the solubility of free bile acids, making them even less carcinogenic.24 The increasingly available free calcium in an acidic environment also binds to the free bile acids and fatty acids.25 There is evidence indicating that butyrate reinforces the colonic defense barrier by inducing the secretion of mucins, trefoil factors, and antimicrobial peptides.26 SCFAs have distinct anti-inflammatory activities due to their regulation of prostaglandin E2, cytokine, and chemokine release from human immune cells.27 They were also shown to enhance intestinal adaptation in short bowel syndrome, possibly mediated via glucagon-like peptide (GLP)–2.28

The roles of the 3 major SCFAs in our metabolism have been summarized in Table 1. Although most members of the microbiota are associated with the fermentation process, Clostridia clusters XIVa and IV of Firmicutes are considered the chief butyrate producers.29 Butyrate is the main energy source for colonic epithelial cells, being preferred over circulatory glucose or glutamine, and up to 90% of it is metabolized by colonocytes.30 It acts as the chief regulator of epithelial growth by inducing proliferation of normal epithelial cells and enhancing differentiation. It suppresses inflammatory mediators such as tumor necrosis factor–α (TNF-α) and nitric oxide, potentiates p53 gene expression and transforming growth factor–β (TGF-β) signaling and its tumor-suppressing activity, and increases the immunogenicity of cancer cells.31-34 Butyrate activates the apoptosis cascade and induces growth arrest of tumors by histone hyperacetylation and exerts immunomodulatory effects by suppressing nuclear factor–κB (NF-κB) activation, a transcription factor controlling the expression of genes encoding proinflammatory responses.35-37 Butyrate’s anticarcinogenic properties have also been attributed to its enhancement of the detoxifying enzyme glutathione-S-transferase activity, as well as inhibition of tumor cell migration and tumor-induced angiogenesis.38-40 It is also proposed to play a role in inducing satiety by modulating gut peptides.41,42

caption.p: The Major Short-Chain Fatty Acids (SCFAs): Their Principle Actions and Mechanisms

tr.td: Metabolism: primary substrate for gluconeogenesis (especially in ruminants), inhibits HMG-CoA → decreased hepatic cholesterol synthesis
Anti-inflammatory: downmodulates intestinal cyclooxygenase activity; stimulates GPCR41 and GPCR43; inhibits NF-κB through PPARγ
Antimicrobial: inhibits expression of the genes facilitating invasion and penetration of the intestinal epithelium by Salmonella typhimurium

Improvement of insulin sensitivity: inhibits lipolysis and promotes lipogenesis in VAT and suppresses FA production in liver → lower FA levels in liver and plasma → lower inflammatory state → mitigates the insulin resistance caused by FA-inflammation interplay
Satiety: promotes satiety via complex neuronal, endocrine, paracrine, and autocrine pathways; influences the production of adipokinetic hormones, such as leptin, a potent anorexigenic hormone

Anticarcinogenic: inhibits HDAC → hyperacetylation of histones and enhancement of the accessibility of transcription factors to nucleosomal DNA → regulates gene expression and cell function; enhances the activity of the detoxifying enzyme glutathione-S-transferase, inhibits tumor cell migration by inhibiting DAF expression and pro-metastatic metalloproteinase activation; inhibits tumor-induced angiogenesis through modulation of angiogenesis-related proteins, VEGF and HIF-1α

Anti-inflammatory: suppresses NF-κB activation through the inhibition of HDAC, inhibition of the interferon-γ production and/or signaling, and the upregulation of PPARγ; acts as a signaling molecule through GPR41 and GPR43
Reinforcement of colonic defense barrier: increases MUC2 gene expression → stimulates mucin synthesis; enhances intestinal trefoil factor (ITF or TFF3) secretion by the intestinal goblet cells
Satiety: via ? GLP-1 or peptide YY
Liver, muscle, and other peripheral tissues
Metabolism: primary substrate for cholesterol synthesis

fn.p: DAF, decay accelerating factor; FA, fatty acid; GLP-1, glucagon-like peptide 1; GPCR, G-protein–coupled receptor; HDAC, histone deacetylase; HIF-1α, hypoxia-inducible factor α; NF-κB, nuclear factor–κB; PPARγ, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ; VAT, visceral adipose tissue; VEGF, vascular endothelial growth factor.

sec.p: Acetate is produced in such large quantities that it is incompletely metabolized and mostly absorbed into the bloodstream.43 It is the primary substrate for acetyl-CoA synthetase-mediated cholesterol synthesis in the adipose tissue, mammary glands, and liver, hence affecting host lipid metabolism.44 Propionate is also mostly taken up by the liver and is used as substrate for gluconeogenesis. It also inhibits hepatic cholesterol synthesis by inhibiting 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA) synthase and HMG-CoA reductase.45,46 High production rates of propionic acid lower the plasma fatty acid levels by inhibiting lipolysis, inducing lipogenesis in adipose tissue and decreasing fatty acid synthesis in the liver, resulting in decreased fatty acid–related inflammation and improved insulin sensitivity.47 Propionate exhibits anti-inflammatory properties by downmodulating intestinal cyclooxygenase activity and inhibiting NF-κB.48,49 It displays antimicrobial activity by inhibiting expression of the genes facilitating invasion and penetration of the intestinal epithelium by Salmonella typhimurium.50 It promotes satiety via complex neuronal, endocrine, paracrine, and autocrine pathways and influences the production of adipokinetic hormones, such as leptin, a potent anorexigenic hormone.51,52

The indigenous microbiota plays an essential role in the development and education of the immune system.53 Studies in GF mice revealed underdeveloped lymphatic systems, fewer Peyer’s patches, isolated lymphoid follicles, fewer intestinal dendritic cells, and poorly formed spleens. The intestinal epithelial cells act as an interface between the gut microbiota and the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT).54 The pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) such as Toll-like receptors (TLRs) on the epithelial cells play a key role in microbial recognition by binding to specific microbial macromolecules.55 TLR signaling via NF-κB pathways, mitogen-activated protein kinase, and caspase- dependent signaling promotes epithelial cell proliferation, secretion of IgA, and expression of antimicrobial peptides.56 Dysregulated cascade of these events can result in a state of unrestrained chronic inflammation and repair that may explain the role of the microbiota in chronic inflammation, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and colorectal carcinogenesis.

sec.title: Microbiota and Disease
sec.p: The influence of gut microbiota and its metabolites is not confined to the intestine. Dysbiosis has been associated not only with the diseases of intestinal mucosa, such as IBD and colon cancer, but also with systemic disorders such as obesity, metabolic syndrome, allergy, autoimmune diseases, diabetes, and liver disease. The implications of dysbiosis are summarized in Figure 2.

caption.p: Gut microbiota participate in the host metabolic homoeostasis, and a disturbed composition/metabolic activity, dysbiosis, is associated with several intestinal as well as systemic diseases. Angptl4, angiopoetin-related protein 4; APC, antigen-presenting cell; DM, diabetes; H2, hydrogen; H2S, hydrogen sulfide; IBD, inflammatory bowel disease; IBS, irritable bowel syndrome; IgA, immunoglobulin A; LPL, lipoprotein lipase; LPS, lipopolysaccharide; NAFLD, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease; PYY, pancreatic peptide YY; SCFA, short-chain fatty acids; Teff, effector T cell; TLR, Toll-like receptor; Treg, regulatory T cell.

sec.title: Colorectal Cancer
sec.p: Colorectal cancer is the third most commonly diagnosed cancer and third most leading cause of cancer death in both men and women in the United States, with around 141,210 new cases and 49,380 deaths expected in 2011, as per an estimate by American Cancer Society. Epidemiological evidence derived from comparative population studies around the world supports the role of diet in CRC development, crediting the indigestible fiber/resistant starch, fruits and vegetables, antioxidants, calcium, and vitamin D with a protective effect and implicating high consumption of red meat and animal fat in increasing risk of colorectal cancer.18

Our hypothesis is that risk from diet is mediated by the microbiota.12 Dietary residues in the colon influence the composition of the colonic microbiota and their metabolites that regulate mucosal proliferation and therefore cancer risk. Thus, diets that generate large quantities of colonic carbohydrate residues (eg, high fiber and high complex carbohydrate) increase microbial fermentation and butyrate production and reduce risk, whereas diets rich in meat and fat stimulate sulfate-reducing bacteria (SRB) production of genotoxic hydrogen sulfide and microbial conversion of bile acids to carcinogenic secondary bile acids, thus increasing risk of colon cancer.57

Meat being a rich source of dietary sulfur (higher content of sulfur–amino acids) promotes the growth of SRB (eg, Desulfovibrio vulgaris), which outcompete methanogenic bacteria for hydrogen to form hydrogen sulfide, a highly toxic compound that impairs cytochrome oxidase, suppresses butyrate utilization, inhibits the synthesis of mucus, and promotes methylation of DNA, which is genotoxic via the generation of free radicals.58,59 The H2 gas, when produced in excess and not converted to methane (by hydrogenotrophic methanogens [eg, Methanobrevibacter smithii], as seen in low-risk rural Africans consuming high–complex carbohydrate diets), can damage the cells by impairing nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) regeneration and inhibiting respiration.60

It has been established that a high-fat diet increases fecal bile acids by stimulating their synthesis and enterohepatic circulation. 7α-Dehydroxylating bacteria convert colonic primary bile acids to secondary bile acids, which are cytotoxic to colonic epithelial cells, mutagenic, and antiapoptotic in animal models.61-63 In addition, hydrophobic bile acids have been shown to promote genomic instability and colorectal carcinogenesis by inducing micronuclei formation, mitotic perturbations, and decreases in spindle checkpoint proteins.64 In our recent study, we analyzed the colonic contents of secondary bile acids and SCFAs in African Americans, Caucasian Americans, and native Africans.22 We noted that dietary fat and total/animal protein intakes were higher in African Americans and Caucasian Americans when compared with native Africans. The amounts of lithocholic acid, deoxycholic acid, and cholic acid were all significantly higher in African Americans than native Africans, with no significant differences noted between the African Americans and Caucasian Americans (Figure 3). In contrast, SCFA content was higher in native Africans compared with the other 2 groups, with the exception of the branched-chain fatty acid, 2-methylvalerate, a derivative of protein fermentation, which was significantly higher in the American groups (Figure 4). These results corroborate our hypothesis that higher risk of colon cancer in Americans compared with the native Africans could be explained by their higher fat intake, which results in higher concentrations of carcinogenic secondary bile acids as a result of harmful bacteria, whereas the lower risk of cancer in the native Africans correlated with higher concentrations of beneficial SCFAs produced by good bacteria.

caption.p: Major bile acid contents in colonic evacuates were significantly lower in native Africans (NAs) compared with African Americans (AAs) and Caucasian Americans (CAs). *P < .05 vs. NAs, Mann-Whitney testing. There was no difference between AAs and CAs. LCA data have been magnified 10 times to be visible on this scale. Bile acid abbreviations: CA, cholic acid; DCA, deoxycholic acid; LCA, lithocholic acid.

Major short-chain fatty acid concentrations in stools (left) and in colonic evacuates (right, previously reported by O’Keefe et al12 ) were significantly higher in native Africans (NAs) compared with African Americans (AAs) and Caucasian Americans (CAs). *P < .05 vs CA and AA; **P < .001 vs CA and AA, Mann-Whitney testing. There were no significant differences between AAs and CAs. Adapted from O’Keefe et al12 and Ou et al.22 Reprinted with permission from Taylor & Francis, http://www.tandfonline.com; and the American Society for Nutrition.

sec.p: However, the situation is far more complex, as not all people eating a high-meat, low-fiber diet get colon cancer, and net risk is determined by multiple interacting factors, including host genetic predisposition, host health, and luminal interactions. For example, many other microbiota disturbances have been associated with colon cancer risk and disease. In a study analyzing the stool samples of 20 patients with colorectal cancer and 17 healthy volunteers, patients with colorectal cancer demonstrated decreased levels of butyrate-producing Eubacterium rectale and Faecalibacterium prausnitzii and increased populations of Enterococcus faecalis when compared with healthy volunteers, suggesting a shift in the colonic bacterial population as a factor leading to colon cancer.65 In another, patients with colorectal cancer had significant elevation of the Bacteroides-Prevotella population.66 Most recently, a very high abundance of Fusobacterium nucleatum, an oral pathogen, usually responsible for periodontitis, was detected in the colorectal tumor tissue.67

Chronic infections resulting in mucosal hyperproliferation and cancer, in cases such as Helicobacter pylori–associated gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, supports the speculated role of a chronic inflammatory state induced by the microbiotal imbalance to be behind the cancer development.68 In a mice model, colonization of enterotoxigenic Bacteroides fragilis, a human colonic commensal bacterium known to cause inflammatory diarrhea, resulted in colitis and strongly induced colonic tumors.69 Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly Streptococcus bovis) is classically associated with colon cancers, although a causative association has not been established.70 The increased risk of colon cancer in patients with ulcerative colitis and even higher risk when the colon is primarily affected point to the fact that inflammation in conjunction with the carcinogenic effects of the bacteria mediates the neoplastic process. C-reactive protein levels in the bloodstream are elevated and suppression of inflammation with aspirin is expected to reduce the risk of cancer development.71,72 Swidsinski et al73 noted that adherent/invasive Escherichia coli strains colonized the colonic mucosa, intracellularly, in patients with colorectal carcinoma and adenoma but not in normal colonic mucosa.

Superoxide-producing E faecalis has been shown to cause epithelial DNA damage with carcinogenic consequences.74 Intestinal bacteria may also promote carcinogenesis by increasing the progression of chemically induced aberrant crypt foci.75 Finally, there is also substantial experimental evidence for the cytotoxicity and mutagenicity of heme.76 Burning meat by grilling or barbequing produces heterocyclic amines, which are potent experimental carcinogens.76,77 The mutagenic effects of bile acids can be inhibited by increased butyrate production from high amylose-resistant maize starch, and the toxicity of heme can be annulled by chlorophyll.78,79 The effects of dietary casein and meat on DNA damage can also be prevented by the simultaneous consumption of resistant starch.80 Lactobacilli can reduce the mutagenic properties of bile acids.
Thus, evidence is compelling that colon cancer risk is determined by interactions between the diet and the colonic microbiota, and it can therefore be mitigated by their modification.

sec.title: Clostridium difficile–Associated Diarrhea
sec.p: Diarrhea resulting from antibiotic usage is the result of an altered microbial diversity and decreased fecal SCFA production by butyrate-producing bacteria.81 Clostridium difficile–associated diarrhea has been a growing problem, with indiscriminate antibiotic usage resulting in microbial imbalance and overgrowth of toxigenic clostridial strains. In a murine model of C difficile infection (CDI), antibiotics were given to disrupt their intestinal colonization resistance followed by C difficile by oral gavage to induce CDI.82 Severe colitis was noted on histopathology in animals that became critically ill with less severe changes noted in those that did well clinically. 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis revealed a dominant Proteobacteria in the gut tissues of the critically ill group, whereas Firmicutes dominated the clinically well group, closely resembling that of an untreated animal group. Thus, severity of disease was felt to be a result of the interplay of clostridial proliferation and ecologic dynamics of indigenous microbiota in the wake of antibiotic use. Fecal bacteriotherapy, transplantation of normal bacterial flora from stool obtained from a healthy donor, has been shown to be remarkably successful in the treatment of chronic recurrent CDI, restoring the numbers of Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes.83

sec.title: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
sec.p: Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, the 2 distinct entities comprising IBD, are a significant health burden in the United States with more than 1.4 million cases.84 There has been a great interest in understanding the role of gut microbiota in the instigation and/or perpetuation of inappropriate inflammatory processes in a genetically predisposed host, with several other environmental factors influencing the pathogenesis of IBD. Rising rates of IBD and other autoimmune diseases in Westernized nations underscore the “hygiene hypothesis,” which implicates excessive use of antibiotics and hygiene practices in depriving the gut immune system of the interaction with “essential” microbes that modulate the evolution of our immune system.85 The gut microbial composition of patients with IBD was noted to be abnormal with a decreased prevalence of Firmicutes, and specifically butyrate producers such as Clostridium IXa and IV groups and Bifidobacteria, and a proportionate increase in bacteria such as sulfate-reducing bacteria and E coli.86 Roediger et al87 first demonstrated the association between SRB overgrowth and acute ulcerative colitis. This might be explained by the metabolite of SRBs, hydrogen sulfide, which has been shown to produce mucosal inflammation and has genotoxic properties, suggesting SRBs may also play a role in colon cancer.59

sec.title: Allergy
sec.p: Associations between allergic disease and altered fecal microbiota, antibiotic use, and dietary factors have been well documented.88 The immunomodulatory effects of intestinal microbiota are essential for immunotolerance through expansion of regulatory T-cell and immunosuppressive cytokines.89 Dysregulation of this complex process results in unwanted immune response toward harmless antigenic stimuli resulting in allergic diseases. Studies of the microbiota in patients with allergies have shown decreased intestinal Bifidobacteria counts, an increased prevalence of B fragilis, and higher counts of Staphylococcus aureus and E coli.90,91

sec.title: Irritable Bowel Syndrome
sec.p: Recent studies analyzing the microbiome of patients with IBS in comparison with healthy counterparts identified specific microbial signatures suggesting their role in IBS pathophysiology. In a pediatric study, the microbiome of 7- to 12-year-old patients with IBS was characterized by a significantly greater percentage of the class γ-proteobacteria, such as Haemophilus parainfluenzae. In addition, IBS was strongly associated with a specific novel Ruminococcus-like microbe, and pain symptoms were related to the presence of genus Alistipes.92 In another study analyzing microbiome of adults with IBS, the intestinal microbiota differed significantly from that of controls with a 2-fold increased ratio of Firmicutes to Bacteroidetes.93 An increase in numbers of Dorea, Ruminococcus, and Clostridium species; a decrease in the number of Bacteroidetes, Bifidobacterium, and Faecalibacterium species; and a lower average number of methanogens were identified. Correlation analysis of the microbial groups and IBS symptom scores indicated the involvement of several groups of Firmicutes and Proteobacteria in the pathogenesis of IBS. Recent experimental and clinical studies suggest that small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, low-grade inflammation, altered gut microbiota, and a dysregulated gut immune system play an important role in the pathogenesis of IBS in addition to a disturbed intestinal motility and gut-brain axis.94

sec.title: Obesity, Insulin Resistance, and Metabolic Syndrome
sec.p: The effect of microbiota on obesity as a causative or modulating entity is the focus of several research studies with evidence mostly from studies in mice. Obese mice (ob/ob, with leptin gene mutation) were found to have 50% more Firmicutes and a proportionate decrease in Bacteroidetes in their gut microbiome when compared with lean (ob/+ and +/+) mice.95 This was associated with increased concentrations of cecal SCFAs, suggesting increased gut microbiotal fermentation and as such an improved energy harvest from the diet.96 Turnbaugh et al97 fed a Western diet to mice and noted a spike in the Mollicutes class of Firmicutes, which was reversed after dietary modification to limit weight gain. Interestingly enough, when the cecal contents of the obese or lean mice were introduced into the small intestine of the lean germ-free mice and equivalent food intakes were provided, there was a greater increase in body fat in the mice that received microbes from obese donors than in those that received the intestinal contents of lean donors.97

Evidence from human studies has been conflicting so far. Ley et al98 noted an increase in the ratio of Firmicutes/ Bacteroidetes in obese individuals when compared with their leaner counterparts and even demonstrated a reverse shift in the gut microbiome toward an increase in the Bacteroidetes proportion reflecting that of lean individuals. However, although some researchers replicated these results, others noted contradictory findings of increased Bacteroidetes/ Firmicutes ratios.99 Differences in the study diets (eg, restriction of fat or carbohydrate in the study by Ley et al) could be one of the several other confounding factors that drive these shifts, and this area of research merits further investigation.

Recent experimental studies suggest that the microbiota also influence body homeostasis and energy balance via a complex network of actions mediated by microbial metabolites (eg, SCFAs and bile acids), gut innate immunity, and the gut neuroendocrine system.100 Key features include the ability of microbiota to suppress enterocyte expression of angiopoietin-like protein 4 (Angpt14), an inhibitor of lipoprotein lipase (LPL), which promotes triglyceride storage in adipose tissue. In addition, SCFAs bind to G-protein–coupled receptors on neuroendocrine L cells in the ileum to release pancreatic peptide YY (PYY), which in turn increases energy harvest and lipogenesis.

Cani et al101 have shown that a high-fat diet in mice resulted in higher plasma levels of lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a component of gram-negative bacteria cell walls, correlating with an increase in their numbers, which were reversed on treatment with an antibiotic. The state of metabolic endotoxemia from higher LPS levels, considered the consequence of increased gut permeability mediated by the gut microbiota, has been proposed to be responsible for chronic low-grade inflammatory states such as diabetes, alcoholic liver disease, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), and metabolic syndrome.101,102 Small intestinal overgrowth of gram-negative organisms also increases endogenous ethanol production and induces choline deficiency, contributing to NAFLD.102

sec.title: Hepatobiliary Disease
sec.p: Dysbiosis is implicated in the susceptibility to alcoholic liver disease. A specific pattern of microbiota has been identified in high-risk heavy drinkers, and colonic microbiota composition is affected by daily alcohol consumption. These findings highlight dysbiosis as an important underlying mechanism of alcohol-induced endotoxemia.103 Cultures of the lithogenic bile grew bacteria belonging to Enterobacteriaceae, Enterococcus, and Streptococcus, indicating a breach in intestinal permeability and a resultant inflammatory response.104 A small study identified bacterial isolates in the bile of only subjects with pigment stones and none from that of healthy subjects, suggesting the association and potential role of gut microbiota in initiating lithogenesis.105 Bacterial analysis of fecal material in cirrhotic patients revealed reduced numbers of beneficial Bifidobacteria.106 Administration of probiotics resulted in lower endotoxin levels, fecal pH, and systemic and fecal ammonia corresponding to higher Bifidobacteria levels in the stool. In another placebo-controlled study conducted in cirrhotic patients with minimal hepatic encephalopathy (MHE), giving synbiotics (probiotic plus fermentable fiber) or fermentable fiber alone resulted in reversal of MHE and improvement in ammonia levels in 50% of the study patients. The mental status of those who did better was associated with significantly increased fecal content of non-urease-producing Lactobacillus species and decreased endotoxin levels.107

sec.title: The Microbe-Gut-Brain Axis
sec.p: The impact of the resident microbiota on general body health is probably far more profound than currently recognized, as recent studies have shown that cardiovascular functional impairments, dysregulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, and decreased perception of inflammatory pain were noted in GF mice.108 The gastrointestinal system communicates with the brain via complex bidirectional signaling pathways regulated at neural, hormonal, and immunological levels, forming a microbe-gut-brain axis.109 In a study investigating the basal behavior of GF mice and conventional mice in a maze, Neufeld et al110 noted that GF mice exhibited less anxious behavior accompanied by decreased mRNA expression of genes implicated in stress-reactivity and anxiety, highlighting the significance of microbiota on the development of behavior. Ongoing research is now focused on unraveling the influence of the microbiota on the gut-brain axis to facilitate new treatment methods for behavioral and functional bowel disorders by modulation of microbiotal composition.

list-item.p: General considerations: It is clear that we were designed to eat a normal balanced diet. A normal balanced diet will support a normal balanced microbiota, which will maintain colonic health and prevent disease, not only in the colon but also in the body.

Personalized medicine: Although a balanced diet will be the most effective approach, there is considerable individual variation in microbiota composition. This is probably explained by the influence of the host on microbial colonization. Thus, the way forward will involve testing microbial composition and their metabolite profiles to determine inflammatory potential in individuals. Specific dietary supplementation, or the use of probiotic species, may then be employed to change the metabolic profile to a noninflammatory one.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Our gastrointestinal tract, especially the colon, is inhabited by trillions of microbes that participate in innumerable metabolic, immunomodulatory, structural, and energy homeostatic functions, making colonic microbiota a vital metabolic organ in its own right. A disturbed composition of the colonic microbiome and internal milieu, as seen in dysbiosis, partners with dietary, genetic, and environmental factors in mediating many diseases in the susceptible host. Advanced techniques have made the challenging task of identifying and characterizing microbes and the microbiome feasible. Equally advanced mathematical and computer-assisted programs will need to be developed to interpret this wealth of new data. Exploration of the details of the host-microbial interactions and elucidation of the involvement of the microbiota in the pathogenesis of a growing list of conditions will expand our understanding of the mechanisms of many human diseases. Manipulation of the microbiota and their metabolites to enhance their beneficial effects on the colon and body health provides an exciting new approach to the management of human disease.
